text: two in my opinion. So I would be very careful with that idea of as many risk mitigations as possible. I'm not even sure that that's the right focus there. If that were me, I would be focusing on the proper risk mitigation. That's what I would think. G33 says stock goes up, call options go down WTF. That's easy. There's a lot of reasons why that can happen. You're fighting a lot of things with call options. You're experiencing stuff like faded decay, where the value of your option is eroding every single day. You're fighting things like changes in volatility. So if the stock moves up a little bit, but not enough to overwhelm faded decay, you'll lose money. Or if the stock moves up a little bit, but not enough to outpace faded decay plus a change in volatility, you'll lose money. That's the tricky part with options is that it starts to bake in new elements into what can happen in our trade. So for example, if we're looking at something, we'll use GME. So I think that's what Benoit was attempting to convey in that scenario. But that's only one scenario in a gross dollar amount. You'll still do better in terms of reducing your risk. So the reason why I say further out of the money, safer for short options as a misconception is because that perception of safety is relative to when risk is eventually realized
